720396f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 34th Street
720396f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, north from, but not including, 34th Street.
In the centre is the Seventy-First Regiment Armory. In a few years
this site will be occupied by the New York Herald Building.
About 1885.
New York Edison Company Collection.

720146f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 34th Street (West)
720146f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue &. Broadway, at West 34th Street as viewed
northward from the Dime Savings Bank on 32nd Street. In
the foreground is the triangular plot identified as Gree-
ley Square. The "El" station at the left is at 33rd Stree
Across the tracks is the continuation of Broadway with the
old 71st 1nf. Regiment Armory to the right. Partially appear-
ing on the right is the Broadway Iabernacle at 34th Street.
Prior to 1892
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717402f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 34th Street
717402f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from and including 34th Street. The
brownstone church in the right foreground is the Broadway Tabernacle.
The only buildings shown which are familiar to modern eyes are the
New York Herald Building, which is shown in the right centre; the
Hotel Normandie, in the centre background, which will be demolished
in 1928; and the Metropolitan Opera House, in the left background,
which will still stand in 1936, with every prospect of surviving for
some years to come. Also shown is the Herald Square Theatre, on the
N.W. corner of 35th Street, and the Hotel Marlborough, on the west
side between 36th and 37th Streets.
About 1895.
Brown Brothers.

709433f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 34th Street (West)
709433f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue and West 34th Street,showing the
Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church,organized in I840,
and building erected in I859.
About I900
No record.

717403f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 34th Street
717403f-a.text:
Broadway at the S.W. corner of 34th Street, showing some of
the buildings which are about to be demolished for the erection
of the new Saks Department Store, which will later be known as
Saks-34th Street.
19O1.
Ewing Galloway.
Neg~ 7.5

709430f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 34th Street (West)
709430f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue (left), at the S. W. corner of West 34th
Street (right), showing the site of the later Saks
Department Store. Note the saloon on the laft operwted
by Jim Corbett, the Worlds heavy weight champion. Dn
the right is Marsh's Restaurant & Cafe.
About 1901
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717404f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 34th Street (West)
717404f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from West 34th Street. The
buildings to the left of the center were removed for the
Macy Dept. Store. The Herald Souare (formerly Park)
Theatre is at the N. W. corner of 35th Street. In the
block above is the Hotel Marlbbro. On the right appears
the Metropolitan Opera building.
About 1901
H. N. Tiemann, photo
00ift of Urbrock Collection

717405f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 34th Street
717405f-a.text:
Broadway at the N.W. corner of34th Street. Almost the entire
picture is taken up by the department store of R. H. Macy & Company;
but the corner building itself is not a part of the store.
About 1922.
Underwood & Underwood.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

717406f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 34th Street
717406f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from 34th to 38th Streets, showing also
34th Street, north side, west from Broadway. The large building
in the centre is Macy's Department Store. Above it is the Johnson
Euilding; the Lefcourt-Marlborough Building, on the site of the
old Marlborough Hotel; the Lefcourt-State Building; and the Bricken-
Broadway Building, on the site of the old Broadway Theatre.
About 1928.
Ewing Galloway.

717409f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 34th Street
717409f-a.text:
R. H. Macy & Comoany, one of New York City's largest department
stores, Broadway, west side, from 35th to 34th Streets. In the
foreground is the former Seventy-First Regiment Armory, half of
which has been demolished for the construction of the Herald Square
Building.
January 30, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

731236f-b.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Macy's Thanksgiving Parade.

731236f-c.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Macy's Thanksgiving Parade.

731236f-a.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Macy's Thanksgiving Parade.

733325f-b.title: Street scenes - Shoppers and crowds.
733325f-b.text:
(1)
Typical noonday street rush at Sixth Ave., and 34th Street, when tower-
ing skyscrapers literally belch humanity into the streets.
About 1921.
(2)
Christmas shoppers at 34th Street and Broadway; one of the World's
busiest corners.
December 24, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

733325f-a.title: Street scenes - Shoppers and crowds.
733325f-a.text:
(1)
Typical noonday street rush at Sixth Ave., and 34th Street, when tower-
ing skyscrapers literally belch humanity into the streets.
About 1921.
(2)
Christmas shoppers at 34th Street and Broadway; one of the World's
busiest corners.
December 24, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

712163f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (West) - 6th Avenue
712163f-a.text:
West 34th Street, east from Sixth Avenue, showing prom-
inently pavement conditions after the removal of the
former streetcar tracks by the W. P. A. At the right
margin is the Hotel HcAlpin. Beyond, at Fifth Avenue,
is the base of the towering Empire State Building. To
the left of the latter is MoCreery's and Altman's stores.
February 7, 1937
W. P. A., photo
Five Boroughs Project

712164f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (West) - Broadway
712164f-a.text:
West 34th Street, west from Broadway, showing pave-
ment conditions after the removal of the former cross-
town street cars and their necessary tracks. The latter
were eliminated through the assistance of the W.P.A.
Note the new bus service on the left. At the right is
Macy's Department Store extending westward to Eighth Ave.
February 7, 1937
W. P. A., photo
Five Boroughs Project

709431f-b.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 34th Street (West)
709431f-b.text:
(1)
6th Avenue, south from W. 34th Street, showing the "Eg"
structure and its 33rd Street Station. This was mainly
patronized by shoppers to Gimbels, Sak's and Macys. The
first two of these enterprizes appear here occupying the
34th - 33rd and 33rdd-32nd Street frontages. Note the
interstore bridge con ecting these.
Views 2 and 3 show the absence of the "Eg" and the station
remaining. This will remmain for about a month and then
join the balance of this structure. Dnderground, at this
date, the 6th Svenue Subway is under construction.
At the left is Broadway, which intersects with 6th Avenue
and leaves two triangular parks; the southerly of which
(Greeley Square) appears partially here.
Viows 1,2 and 3tApril 5, 1939.
P.L.5perr

709431f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 34th Street (West)

(1)

(1)

712165f-a.title: Manhattan: 34th Street (West) - Broadway
712165f-a.text:
Interior Hacy's Je)t. Store N.Y.C.
Shop:ers at Hacys.

709434f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - 34th Street
709434f-a.text:
Sixth Ave., east side, north from but not including 34th Street.
February 5, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

720147f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 34th Street (West)
720147f-a.text:
Broadway south from west 34th Street, also south
on 3ixth Avenue The triangular plot in the center
is Greeley Square and acboss it is the Un'on
Dime Savings Tank Building a west 33nd 3treet.
M2BR.  A.

720395f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 34th Street (West)
720395f-a.text:
Broadway, north across West 34th Street. At the right is
the open triangular area, Herald iouare, identified with
the distinctive Herald Building at it's base. This is formod
by the intersection of Broadway and Sixth Avenue.
About 1901
Gift of Urbrock Collection  ea EtGSS

720397f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 34th Street (West)
720397f-b.text:
Herald Square, north from West 34th Street, showing Broadway
(left) intersecting Sixth Ave. (right, elevated line thereon). At the
apex (West 35th Street) is the 3-story Rogers Peet Building (formerly
the New York Herald Building). At the rear of same and occupying
the balance of the triangke.is the new 24-story Herald Square Building.
September 29, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
Broadway A 6h Ave. Neg. A-243  July 18, 1941
P.L. Sperr

720397f-c.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 34th Street (West)
720397f-c.text:
Herald Square, north from West 34th Street, showing Broadway

717407f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 34th Street
717407f-a.text:
1319-1321 Broadway, west side, between 34th and 35th Streets,
one of the buildings to be torn down for the erection of the
department store of R. H. Macy & Company.
1901.
Ewing Galloway.
